The renowned Cultural Center of Fine Arts (CCA) in Beijing has announced that it is preparing to welcome visitors back to the venue in 2020, after a temporary closure due to the Covid-19 pandemic. The institution said that the reopening of the historic venue will allow it to “provide audiences with the latest in Chinese art and contemporary art.”Culture Minister Gao Yansong told the South China Morning Post that it is all about the future of the collection and about creating a more synergistic environment for art in China. “The current situation is very challenging,” Gao said. “The restoration is one of the most important projects that will give rise to a new new era, and transform the Cultural Center of Fine Arts into an institution that is proud of being a museum of China.”

Arts galleries in Japan are now reeling from a wave of cancellations and postponements owing to the pandemic. The country’s culture ministry announced last week that it expects the number of cancellations to spike this year, and that there will be a further drop in numbers in 2020. The ministry has also announced that it will be reducing the number of exhibitions it hosts, reducing the number of visitors, and cutting the number of performances it holds.In an attempt to mitigate the fallout from the coronavirus, Japanese state broadcaster NHK reported this week that the number of visitors from abroad will rise this year, and that the number of visitors from Japan will rise by 20 percent in 2020. According to a report published by the Japanese Ministry of Economy, Trade, and Industry (METI), the number of foreign tourists visiting Japan in 2020 is expected to reach 51.3 million, up from 34.3 million last year. The number of visitors from the United States is expected to remain the same, at 35.7 million, as last year, but will increase by 10 percent.
